medical: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Right AC separation. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Right AC separation. PROCEDURES: Removal of the hardware and revision of right AC separation. ANESTHESIA: General. BLOOD LOSS: 100 cc. COMPLICATIONS: None. FINDINGS: Loose hardware with superior translation of the clavicle implants. IMPLANTS: Arthrex bioabsorbable tenodesis screws. SUMMARY: After informed consent was obtained and verified, the patient was brought to the operating room and placed supine on the operating table. After uneventful general anesthesia was obtained, he was positioned in the beach chair and his right shoulder was sterilely prepped and draped in a normal fashion. The incision was reopened and the hardware was removed without difficulty. The AC joint was inspected and reduced. An allograft was used to recreate the coracoacromial ligaments and then secured to decorticate with a bioabsorbable tenodesis screw and then to the clavicle. And two separate areas that were split, one taken medially and one taken laterally, and then sewed together for further stability. This provided good stability with no further superior translation of the clavicle as viewed under fluoroscopy. The wound was copiously irrigated and the wound was closed in layers and a soft dressing was applied. He was awakened from anesthesia and taken to recovery room in a stable condition. Final needle and instrument counts were correct.
layman:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Right AC joint separation.  
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Right AC joint separation.  
PROCEDURES: Removed old hardware and repaired the right AC joint.  
ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia.  
BLOOD LOSS: 100 cc.  
COMPLICATIONS: None.  
FINDINGS: Old hardware was loose and the clavicle had moved upward.  
IMPLANTS: Arthrex bioabsorbable tenodesis screws.  

SUMMARY: After the patient gave informed consent, he was taken to the operating room and laid on his back. General anesthesia was given without problems. He was then positioned in a beachâ€‘chair position and the right shoulder was cleaned and covered with sterile drapes. The surgeon reopened the old incision and removed the hardware easily. The AC joint was examined and put back into place. A donated tendon was used to rebuild the coracoacromial ligaments. The tendon was fixed to the clavicle with a bioabsorbable screw and the two split parts of the tendon were sewn together for extra stability. Fluoroscopy showed the clavicle was no longer moving upward. The wound was washed thoroughly, closed in layers, and a soft dressing was applied. The patient woke up from anesthesia and went to the recovery room in stable condition. All needles and instruments were counted correctly.
